2: The present study was designed to directly compare effects of temporal abstraction, relational abstraction, and integration. On each trial, subjects received 2 cues (see Fig. 1): one denot- ing a concrete feature (feature cue; e.g., “green”) and another “ denoting an abstract relationship (relation cue; e.g., and”). “
Thereafter, subjects were shown 2 objects ( probe) and made a decision on the basis of the feature and relationship (e.g., are both objects “ green?”).
The task was designed to contrast effects of temporal abstraction, rela- tional abstraction, and integration
